Theatre Royal, Drury Lane.
The variou« Continental Engagements, which have been some time since concluded by the Lessee of this
Theatre, being about to commence, the public attention is respectfully directed to the following arrangments for
the remainder of the season :—
Having already secured (as permanent members of his company,) the PRINCIPAL NATIVE TALENT
the Lessee has, by an unlimited expenditure, succeeded in engaging- the MOST EMINENT PERFORMERS
from Italy, Germany, and France; thus uniting in honourable competition, and in every Scenic variety, the combined powers of the principal artists of Europe. He, therefore, begs leave to submit the names of the various
persons wtio, in conjunction with the leading- Performers of the British Stage, will appear in succession until til.
tdose of the Theatre.

general accommodation of the Public, a select number of ORCHESTRA SEATS have been provided, the entrance to which will be by the Private Box Door, in Russell Street; and for die
convenience of persons securing them, a handsowe entree room has lieenfittedup.

In order to render the Musical Department of this Establishment more complete, for this particular occasion,
engagements have been entered into with the following- eminent Professors, in addition to the usual
strength of the Band:—

Theatre Royal, P r a i y Lane.
The various Continental Engagements, whi.li have been some time sines concluded by the Leasee of this
Theatre, being about to commence, the public attention is respectfully directed to th. following arrangment* for
the remainder of the season :—
Having already secured (as permanent members of his company,) the PRINCIPAL NATIVE TALENT
the Lessee has, by an unlimited expenditure, succeeded in engaging the MOST EMINENT PERFORMERS
from Italy, Germany, and France; thus uniting in honourable competition, and in every Scenic variety, the combined powers of the principal artists of Europe. He, therefore, begs leave to submit the names of the various
persons who, in conjunction with the leading Performers of the British Stage, will appear in succession until the
close of the Theatre.

general accommodation of the Public, a select number of ORCHESTRA SEATS have been provided, the entrance to which will lie by the Private Box Door, in Russell Street; and for the
eonvenience of persons securing them, a handsome entrSe room has beenfittedup.

The T r i u m p h a n t success of DON J U A N

'

The various Continental Engagements, which have been some time since concluded by the Lessee of this
Theatre, being about to commence, the public attention is respectfully directed to the following arrangments for
the remainder of the season :—
Having already secured (as permanent members of his company,) the PRINCIPAL NATIVE TALENT
the Lessee has, by an unlimited expenditure, succeeded in engaging the MOST EMINENT PERFORMERS
from Italy, Germany, and France; thus uniting in honourable competition, and in every Scenic variety, the combined powers of the principal artists of Europe. He, therefore, begs leuve*Ho submit the names of the various
persons who, in conjunction with the leading Performers of the British Stage, will appear in succession until the
close of the Theatre.
PRINCIPAL MEMBERS FORMING T H E ENGLISH COMPANY:

P A U L ,

Principal Dancer of the Academic Royale.

Monsieur
S I L V A I N,
Monsieur
G I L B E R T.

English Theatre.
Ballet Master.
Monsieur A N A T H O L E.
(From the Academie Royale, ot Paris, and late of the King's Theatre, London,)

ftp In order to mewt the wishes of numerous distinguished patrons of the Drama, andforthe
general accommodation of the Public, a select number of ORCHESTRA SEATS have been provided, the entrance to which will be by the Private Box Door, in Russell Street; and for the
convenience of persons securing them, a handsome entree room has beenfittedup.
The Prices of Admission to the different parts of the Theatre will he as follow:—

' ' '

The various Continental Engagements, whieh have been some time since concluded by the Lessee of this
Theatre, being about to commence, the public attention is respectfully directed to the following arrangments for
the remainder of the season :—
Having already secured (as permanent members of his company,) the PRINCIPAL NATIVE TALENT
the Lessee has, by an unlimited expenditure, succeeded in engaging the MOST EMINENT PERFORMERS
flora Italy, Germany, and France; thus uniting in honourable competition, and in every Scenic variety, the combined powers of the principal artists of Europe. He, therefore, begs leave to submit the names of the various
persons who, in conjunction with the leading Performers of the British Stage, will appear in succession until tit*
close of the Theatre.
PRINCIPAL MEMBERS FORMING T H E E N G L I S H COMPANY:

ENVIRONS OF SEVILLE.

Theatre, being uboM to commence, the public a'tention is respectfully directed to the following' arrangments for
the remainder ot the season :—
Having already secured (as permanent members of his company,) the PRINCIPAL NA.TTVF TALENT
the Lessee has, by an unlimited expenditure, succeeded in engaging the MOST EMINENT Ph'KFOKMERS
from Italv, Germany, and France; thus uniting in honourable competition, and in every Scenic variety, the combined powers of the principal ariists of Luiope He, therefore, begs leave to submit the names of the variou*
persons who, in conjunction w.th the leading Performers of the British Stage, will appear in succession until tli.
i lose of the Theatre.

VIEW I N T H E ENVIRONS OF SEVILLE.

Gardens of Don Juan s Palace decorated for a fete Champctre.
T H E C E M E T E R Y AND CATHEDRAL AT SEVILLE,

Theatre Royal, Drury Lano.
The various Continental Engagements, which have been some time since concluded by the Lessee of this
Theatre, being about to commence, the public attenti.ii ii respectfully directed to th» following arrangmants for
the remainder of the season ;—
Having already secured (as permanent members of his company',) the PRINCIPAL NATIVE TALENT
the Lessee has, by an tmlimiled expenditure, succeeded in engaging the MOST EMINENT PERFORMERS
from Italy, Germany, and France; thus uniting in honourable competition, and in every Seenic variety, the combined powers of the principal artists of Europe. He, therefore, begs leave to submit the names of the various
persons who, in conjunction with the leading Performer"* of the llritish Stage, will appear in succession until the
close of the Theatre.

KIT The Entertainments announced at this Theatre
for this Evening having been prohibited, at the instigation of the BISHOP OF LONDON, notwithstanding
the License granted for STAGE PERFORMANCES
to other Theatres in the Metropolis on the same Evening,
the Lessee respectfully informs the Public, that this
Establishment will be closed To-night, to enable him more
effectually to prepare such a Variety of Entertainments
p%r the ensuing Wednesdays and Fridays in Lent, as he
trusts will meet with their approbation.

6HF The Entertainments announced at this Theatre
for last Friday having been prohibited, at the instigation of the BISHOP OF LONDON, notwithstanding
the License granted for STAGE PERFORMANCES
to other Theatres in the Metropolis on the same Etening,
the Lessee respectfully informs the Public, that he is
preparing such a Variety of Entertainments for the ensuing Wednesdays and Fridays in Lent, as he trusts will
meet with their approbation.

To-morrow. WEDNESDAY, Feb. 27 1833,

KEAN,

The public is respectfully Informed, that the engagement of that gentleman at this
Theatre, does not expire until the30th inst., which engagement ha» only been suspended
by the receipt of the following certificate from Mr. KEAN's Medical adviser:

until

Mr. K E A N,

The public is respectfully informed, that the engagement of that gentleman a t this
Theatre, does not expire until the 30th inst., which engagemen t ha. only been suspended
by the receipt of the following certificate from Mr. KEAN's Medical adviser :—
" Mr. JAMES SMITH presents his Compliments to Mr. BUNN, he is sorry to
" inform him that Mr. KEAN is confined by so very severe an attack of Gout in his
" right hand and arm, and some threatening also of the same sort in the legs, as to
" render it QUITE IMPOSSIBLE for him to perform at present.

" Mr. J. SMITH
will be happy to inform Mr. BUNN. from day to day, how
" Mr. KEAN goes on, as it is impossible at present tofixthe day for his re-appearance.
" Richmond Green, March 12th, 1833."

Fourth Night of the New GRAND OPERA.

Theatre MoifM^Mf^ifLune
Madame M A U B R A N 9
LA S O N N A M B U L A ,

Continuing to be received with a degree of enthusiasm never exceeded
in any Theatre, and her entire performance throughout the Opera of

having commanded the deepest attention and sympathy of the whole
audience, and that Opera having been altogether highly successful,
she will repeat the Character of AMINA,
THREE TIMES EVERY WEEK UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE.

Tp-morrow, TUESDAY, May 7, 1833,
Their Majesties' Servants will perform {for the Fourth Time) a New Grand Opera, entitled

!•A S O N N A M B U L A
(With the whole of the Music by the celebrated composer BELLINI, finr the 3rd time o it the English Stage)

Mr

The Dresses by Mr. Palmer ami Mrs. Coombe. The Machinery by Mr. Nail. The Decorations by Mr. Blamire
£%" In order to give all possible eif'ret to this Opera, the Chorusses will be increased, and the Band will be
considerably augmented, by the aid of several eminent professors from the King's Theatre, the l'bilarnionic, and
the Concerts of Ancient Music.

tlw Theatre will be Closed this Evening:
The Public is respectfully informed, that the celebrated Singer,

Madame M A U B R A N .
has arrived in this Country, to fulfil the Engagement entered into by
her with the Lessee of this Theatre, and will make her first appearance
To-morrow Evening, W E D N E S D A Y , May 1, 1833,
On which occasion their Majesties' Servants will produce, {for the First Time) a New Grand Opera, entitled

LA SONNAMBULA
(With the whole of the Music l»/ the celebrated composer BELLINI, for the first time on the English Stage)
Arranged and Adapted to the English Stage by Mr. H. R. BISHOP.

Mr

considerably augmented, by the aid of several eminent professors from the King's Theatre, the I'hilarmomc, and
the Concerts of Ancient Music.

Third Night of the New GRAND OPERA.

Theatre HoyraE, JDrurgffJLane
*S* The Public is respectfully informed, that in consequence of the indisposition of
H E R R H A I T Z I N G E R , it has been deemed advisable to postpone the first performance
o / F I D E L I O , until Monday next, to prevent further disappointment. Tickets issuedf*r
this Evening will be admitted on Monday, or the Money paid for them wilt be returned.
T H E T H E A T R E W I L L T H E R E F O R E B E CLOSED T H I S EVENING.

L A SONNAMBULA

The Public is respectfully requested to take notice that the Engagement of Madame MALIBRAN,
only extends to a few Evenings, and
that in consequence of the great demand for Places to witness her performance, (theFree List, with the exception of the Public Press) will be suspended.

In consequence of the enthusiastic reception, and brilliant audiences,
which have attended the Performance of

Madame M A L I B R A f ,
A RE-ENGAGEMENT, FOR A F E W NIGHTS, has been concluded
with that distinguished Artiste, and she will make h e r Appearance in
Monsieur CHELARD's New Opera, on Tuesday next.

Cfi-aiid Musical Festival.

Peeresses, Judges, Bishops, Knights, Heralds, Pursuivants, Choristers, &c. &c. assisting at the Coronation.

of St. Edward. The CROWN being placed on bis Head by the Archbishop,
